When a boat is travelling upstream, its speed is reduced by the speed of the current. So, if the speed of the boat in still water is x km/hr and the speed of the current is y km/hr, then the speed of the boat upstream will be (x - y) km/hr.

=> 0.6x - 0.6y = y
=> 0.6x = 1.6y
=> x = (1.6y) / 0.6

Now, it is also given that the speed of the boat in still water is 240 km/hr. So, we can substitute this value of x in the above equation:
=> 240 = 8y/3
=> 8y = 240 * 3
=> 8y = 720
=> y = 720 / 8
=> y = 90
Therefore, the speed of the current is 90 km/hr. And, the upstream speed of the boat is:
=> x - y = 240 - 90
=> x = 150 km/hr
Hence, the correct option is C: 150.
